definition:
Let $X$ be an infinite set. We define the *countable complement
topology* on $X$ by declaring the empty set to be open, and a non-empty
subset $U\subset X$ to be open if $X\backslash U$ is countable.

If $X$ is countable, then the countable complement topology is just the
discrete topology, as the complement of *any* set is countable and thus
open.

Though defined similarly to the finite complement topology, the
countable complement topology lacks many of the strong compactness
properties of the finite complement topology. For example, the countable
complement topology on an uncountable set gives an example of a
topological space that is not weakly countably compact (but *is*
pseudocompact).
